name: Democratic Republic of the Congo
currentCrisisSummary:
Eastern DRC is the epicentre of a long-running, deadly contest over vast mineral wealth â€” cobalt, coltan, tin and gold â€” that are critical to global tech and renewable-energy supply chains.

This has produced what many analysts call 'green colonialism' or 'green imperialism': the Global North's clean-energy transition depends on supply chains that are tied to violence, economic dispossession and child labour in the Global South. Armed control over mines, opaque trade routes and corporate purchasing practices link multinational companies to a system that extracts value while externalising the human cost.

The conflict involves the Congolese armed forces, scores of local militias and foreign-backed groups such as M23. Regional interference, notably allegations of Rwandan and Ugandan support for proxy militias, has fuelled repeated cycles of violence, mass displacement and severe protection crises. Sexual violence is widely used as a tactic of war, and eastern provinces face repeated waves of forced displacement, food insecurity and attacks on civilians.

Humanitarian needs are enormous, with mass displacement and extreme violence ranking the crisis among the world's deadliest since World War II. Accountability has been limited, with UN reports and civil-society investigations documenting widespread abuses and illegal exploitation of resources. Ending the crisis requires halting external military interference, enforcing corporate transparency across supply chains, and centring Congolese-led justice and development.

colonialRoot.legacy:
The contemporary crisis is rooted in Belgium's extraction-first colonial project. King Leopold II's Congo Free State treated the territory as a private resource, unleashing forced labour, violence and mass mortality to extract rubber and other commodities. After 1908, Belgian state rule continued a political economy designed for extraction rather than local development.

Belgian colonial institutions prioritised mineral concession systems, segregated labour regimes and elite-friendly governance that hollowed out public institutions and legal protections. The post-independence state inherited weak institutions, clientelist networks and externally oriented extraction models that made the region vulnerable to predatory neighbours, multinational corporations and armed actors seeking control of mineral rents.

historicalContext.conflictMineralsAndForeignInfluence:
Eastern Congo's mineral wealth sits at the intersection of local militias, regional strategic interests and global markets. Armed groups and complicit intermediaries control mines, tax artisanal production and smuggle valuable minerals into international supply chains. Investigations by UN panels, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch document forced evictions, labour abuses and supply-chain opacity that connect extractive industries to human-rights violations.

The demand for minerals associated with electronics, batteries and vehicles creates incentives for territorial control by armed groups and for states to project influence across borders. Corporate due-diligence gaps and weak regulatory enforcement in sourcing countries allow these systems to persist.
historicalContext.thePostColonialStateAndExternalInterfere: Post-colonial Congo has repeatedly been shaped by foreign interventions and geopolitical manoeuvring. The assassination of Patrice Lumumba with Belgian and US complicity undermined early attempts at sovereign resource control. Subsequent authoritarian rule under Mobutu entrenched kleptocratic extraction and weakened state capacity. Regional wars (1996-2003) and continuing interventions by neighbouring states turned eastern DRC into a theatre where access to resources, counter-insurgency and regional rivalry overlap, sustaining long-term instability.
historicalContext.internationalLawAndAccountability: Multiple international mechanisms have engaged with the DRC crisis. The UN Group of Experts on the DRC has repeatedly documented regional support for armed groups and illicit exploitation of resources (notably in reports such as S/2024/432). National and international investigations, civil-society documentation and occasional prosecutions have exposed abuses, but systemic accountability remains limited. Remedies require both criminal accountability for serious violations and structural reforms to ensure resource governance, corporate responsibility and reparations for affected communities.

humanitarianImpact.casualties: Conflict-related deaths since the late 1990s likely number in the millions.
humanitarianImpact.affected: Roughly 25.4 million people in need of humanitarian assistance.
humanitarianImpact.displaced: Nearly 7 million people internally displaced, the highest level in recent DRC history.
humanitarianImpact.refugees: More than 1 million DRC refugees and asylum-seekers in neighbouring countries.
humanitarianImpact.childrenOutOfSchool: Millions of children out of school due to conflict and displacement.
humanitarianImpact.sexualViolence: Sexual and gender-based violence is endemic; tens of thousands of survivors treated annually.
humanitarianImpact.livelihoodsAndEconomicLoss: Mining communities face dispossession and forced labour as armed groups control resources.

timeline.event: **Congo Free State**: King Leopold II establishes the Congo Free State as his private possession. The concessionary extraction regime and forced labour policies cause catastrophic population loss and trauma.
**Belgian Colonial Rule**: The Belgian state takes formal control and continues an extraction-centred governance model that privileges foreign companies and creates weak local institutions.
**Independence & Crisis**: The DRC gains independence. Political turmoil, secessionist movements and foreign interference quickly destabilise the new state.

**Assassination of Patrice Lumumba**: The first prime minister is removed and murdered with foreign complicity, a pivotal moment that undercut Congo's early pursuit of independent resource sovereignty.

**Regional Wars & Resource Wars**: The First and Second Congo Wars draw in multiple neighbouring states and armed groups, driven in part by competition over mineral wealth and regional power contests.

**Persistent Violence & Armed Groups**: Eastern provinces host scores of armed groups contesting land, mines and influence. International and corporate supply chains increasingly draw attention to human-rights abuses linked to mineral extraction.

**UN Group of Experts Reports**: UN panels and Security Council reporting document patterns of illicit resource exploitation and regional support for armed groups, naming actors and networks involved in cross-border dynamics.

**Escalation and Displacement**: Renewed advances by M23 and other armed actors trigger mass displacement, the capture of towns and cities in the east, and a sharp rise in protection needs and civilian suffering.

donate.description: A Congolese-led advocacy organisation that raises global awareness and supports local institutions and Congolese voices.
Founded by Dr Denis Mukwege, Panzi provides medical, psychosocial and legal support to survivors of sexual violence and their families.
The UN refugee agency provides protection, shelter and essential aid to internally displaced people and refugees affected by the DRC crisis.

advocacy: Press for independent, enforceable corporate due diligence across mineral supply chains and demand transparency from tech and automotive companies about sourcing.
Support targeted sanctions and diplomatic pressure against external actors found to be materially supporting armed groups, while protecting humanitarian access.
Amplify Congolese civil-society voices and support local organisations that lead relief, protection and accountability work.
Call for reparative measures from states and corporations that profited from exploitative extraction and colonial-era abuses.
Promote conflict-sensitive, community-led development that prioritises land rights, local stewardship of resources and diversification beyond raw-extraction economies.

reading.title: King Leopold's Ghost: A Story of Greed, Terror, and Heroism in Colonial Africa
reading.description: Adam Hochschild's account of the brutal exploitation of the Congo Free State and the international movement that exposed it.

reading.title: Cobalt Red: How the Blood of the Congo Powers Our Lives
reading.description: An investigation linking cobalt mining in the DRC to corporate supply chains, labour abuses and environmental harms.

reading.title: Dancing in the Glory of Monsters: The Collapse of the Congo and the Great War of Africa
reading.description: By Jason Stearns. Though centred on the DRC, this book provides essential context on the regional dynamics of conflict, resource extraction, and state failure in Central Africa.

reading.title: The Assassination of Lumumba
reading.description: Ludo De Witte's research into the role of Belgian and foreign services in the removal and murder of Patrice Lumumba.
